title: Marinated Turkey Breast Recipe
description: This turkey breast marinade combines fragrant aromatics with a tangy sauce, imparting moisture and flavor to the turkey before grilling to perfection.
body: ​ Skip to content Allrecipes Search Please fill out this field. Search the site Please fill out this field. About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Meat and Poultry Turkey Turkey Breast Marinated Turkey Breast 4.6 (287) 231 Reviews 19 Photos This turkey breast marinade recipe came from my mother. These always turn out juicy and tender no matter how long my husband leaves them on the grill. It's easy to prepare but always best when marinated for at least 4 hours. Submitted by Danielle Updated on August 12, 2022 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 19 19 19 19 Prep Time: 20 mins Cook Time: 30 mins Additional Time: 4 hrs 10 mins Total Time: 5 hrs Servings: 12 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 12 servings 2 cloves garlic, peeled and minced 1 tablespoon finely chopped fresh basil ½ teaspoon ground black pepper 2 (3 pound) boneless turkey breast halves 6 whole cloves ¼ cup vegetable oil ¼ cup soy sauce 2 tablespoons lemon juice 1 tablespoon brown sugar Directions Mix garlic, basil, and pepper together in a small bowl; rub over turkey breasts. Insert 1 clove into each end of turkey breasts and 1 in the center. Mix oil, soy sauce, lemon juice, and brown sugar in a large, shallow dish. Place turkey in the dish and turn to coat. Cover and marinate in the refrigerator at least 4 hours. Preheat an outdoor grill for high heat and lightly oil the grate. Discard marinade and place turkey on the preheated grill. Close the lid and cook until turkey is no longer pink in the center and the juices run clear, about 15 minutes on each side. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 165 degrees F (74 degrees C). Editor's Note: Nutrition data for this recipe includes the full amount of marinade ingredients. The actual amount of marinade consumed will vary. I Made It Print 369 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 317 Calories 6g Fat 2g Carbs 60g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 12 Calories 317 % Daily Value * Total Fat 6g 8% Saturated Fat 1g 6% Cholesterol 164mg 55% Sodium 405mg 18% Total Carbohydrate 2g 1% Dietary Fiber 0g 1% Total Sugars 1g Protein 60g 120% Vitamin C 1mg 2% Calcium 31mg 2% Iron 3mg 18% Potassium 597mg 13% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Marinated Turkey Breast 01 of 19 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 19 Photo by  WittyPrawn6467 01/12/2025 Easy to follow Great flavors A keeper! Great recipe & mom approved lol! Recipe was overall great with personal preference used.•I used a little less amount of the sugar & cloves written for personal taste. I used clove powder. Again, just kinda tweaked the amount to less.•I left it marinating overnight & it still tasted great, wasn’t overbearing! Cooked it in the leftover sauces then just added a bit of water until tender to taste.•Used a stovetop instead of outdoor grill, same great taste. 03 of 19 Photo by  babygir52489 11/26/2024 A keeper! Great flavors Crowd-pleaser Easy to follow Family favorite This is a staple to the table every year! Everyone’s favorite. Tastes amazing. I’ve been making for a long time. The marinade is just perfect. Smells amazing and tastes delicious. Also put in baby potatoes with the Turkey breast. I added some citrus for aesthetic. 04 of 19 Photo by  Patrick Nolan 04/10/2019 This recipe is the BOMB! My daughter just harvested her first wild Turkey and was so excited to cook and eat it. I've had wild Turkey before and it always had a wild taste and was so dry and tough. So I found this recipe and see what it could do for wild Turkey. I am so happy to report it was THE BEST Turkey I've ever had wild or domestic. I followed the recipe exactly except for the cloves since I didn't have any. It had awesome flavor and was very tender and surprisingly juicy! I will definitely be saving and referring back to this one in the future! 05 of 19 Photo by  Wildrose4life 12/03/2016 Turned out beautiful! I cooked mine in a bag with veggies to savor more taste. I added cinnamon and a dash of chili Pepper for the seasoning. Yummy 06 of 19 Photo by  Mike F. 10/17/2016 Amazing, I slow smoked to breasts on a weber kettle with briquettes and pecan wood untill internal temp. Reached 175. Made turkey club subs with the left overs. 07 of 19 Photo by  Mrs[K] 08/23/2015 Do yourself a favor: take a break from chicken and use turkey breasts and give your oven a rest and use your grill...you won't regret it! I cut up some zucchini, red onion, portabella mushrooms, and yellow peppers (coated in olive oil, sea salt & ground pepper) and grilled them on the top rack of my gas grill while the turkey cooked below it. It was all amazing...turkey was super juicy and loaded with flavor for a change...and since I grilled everything it was a blissfully easy cleanup! ?? 08 of 19 Photo by  JPB 08/18/2015 I have grilled / indirect heat roasted , whole turkeys before in the traditional way , but this method for breast meat only is a real winner . Family loves it and requested it for our thanks giving day feast. 09 of 19 Photo by  Rock_lobster 04/13/2015 Marinated Turkey Breast Haiku: "Terrific turkey! Only one small swap I made, had to use ground cloves." Truth-time: I've never had turkey other than Thanksgiving baked turkey, and deli sandwich turkey. For real. I'm so glad that I picked up turkey breast at the butcher and made this recipe b/c it was absolutely wonderful. Marinade is similar to my favorite AR "Pretty Chicken Marinade", so I can't give this any less than 5 stars for easy ingredients (as mentioned, I only used ground cloves, maybe 1/4 tsp, instead of whole cloves) and a great flavor on a birdie part that I've never grilled b4. 10 of 19 Photo by  jen 05/18/2014 This was amazing! I subtracted the clove but kept the rest the same. Big hit in my household! 1 2 Next You’ll Also Love Garlic Ranch Chicken 152 Ratings Spicy Chicken Breasts 704 Ratings RamJam Chicken 390 Ratings Unbelievable Chicken 2,423 Ratings Memorial Day Best BBQ Chicken Ever! 50 Ratings Chicken Satay 574 Ratings Hawaiian Chicken Pineapple Kabobs 798 Ratings Jamaican Jerk Chicken 111 Ratings Grilled Shrimp and Apple Skewers 103 Ratings Fiery Fish Tacos with Crunchy Corn Salsa 956 Ratings New York Finger Lakes Chicken 11 Ratings Grilled Chile-Lime Turkey Breast Juicy Grilled Chicken Breasts 504 Ratings Honey Key Lime Grilled Chicken 61 Ratings Texas BBQ Chicken 71 Ratings Easy Grilled Teriyaki Chicken 466 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: Danielle
instructions: Mix garlic, basil, and pepper together in a small bowl; rub over turkey breasts. Insert 1 clove into each end of turkey breasts and 1 in the center.;Mix oil, soy sauce, lemon juice, and brown sugar in a large, shallow dish. Place turkey in the dish and turn to coat. Cover and marinate in the refrigerator at least 4 hours.;Preheat an outdoor grill for high heat and lightly oil the grate.;Discard marinade and place turkey on the preheated grill. Close the lid and cook until turkey is no longer pink in the center and the juices run clear, about 15 minutes on each side. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 165 degrees F (74 degrees C).
